svcsubsecinfo.para: This section includes Troubleshooting Charts for International installed circuits and components that are part of the Caterpillar electronic engine control system. To begin the troubleshooting process, refer to the appropriate Caterpillar Troubleshooting Manuals and follow their directions. If the Caterpillar diagnostics indicate that a International circuit is suspect, use the trouble- shooting charts in this section for a step-by-step procedure.

The MPSI Pro-Link 9000 can be used to read fault codes, customer parameters and engine parameters. The Pro-Link can also monitor various switches and sensors and perform some testing with the Caterpillar cartridge.

item.para: Gather information by talking to the driver if possible. Determine the exact symptoms.
When did the symptoms begin (and what else happened at that time?)
Verify the problem. Is the complaint due to mis-understood customer selected parameters? Use the Pro-Link 9000 to review CUSTOMER SPECIFIED PARA- METERS.
Check for and record any logged fault codes.
Do the logged codes correlate to probable causes?
Did they occur at the same time as the symptoms (and are they logged repeatedly)?
Are the logged codes related to other symptoms? Do they have a common cause?
AVOID PRECONCEIVED IDEAS! Eliminate any NON-ELECTRONIC causes for the problem first (contaminated fuel, clogged air filters, etc).
Analyze logged fault codes and determine probable causes. Fault codes are listed in the Caterpillar manual and in the Prolink diagnostic tool.
Test each probable cause using tests suggested by the procedure. Investigate the most likely causes first. Perform visual inspection ( especially connector checks) before beginning the procedures!
